news.title: 77 people killed in more than 1 000 accidents
news.content:
Story by John Nhandara
The Zimbabwe Republic Police (ZRP) has reported a surge in fatalities on the country’s roads, with 77 people losing their lives in over 1 000 traffic accidents recorded during the 12-day period from the 15th to the 26th of December.
Police spokesperson, Commissioner Paul Nyathi said while fatalities increased, the total number of accidents recorded declined, compared to the same period last year.
“We recorded 1211 road traffic accidents 65 fatal accidents, with 77 people being killed. 401people were injured,” he said.

news.title: Zimbabwe students excel in Cambridge examinations
news.content:
Story by Wellington Makonese
The wave of academic excellence continues to sweep across the country as demonstrated by outstanding results in the recently-released Cambridge Primary Checkpoint Results.The results, released earlier this month, reveal sweeping pass rates across various subjects with most schools that include Samuel Centenary Junior School, Havard Junior School and St Martins Allure Elementary clocking 100% pass rates.
Among them is wizkid Rugare Mutendi, whose exceptional performance has ignited dreams of a future in medicine.
“I’m super excited about my achievement and now looking forward to do sciences at a better level and be a doctor the exams where quite decent,” Rugare says.
The consistent performance over the years highlights the dedication and strength of Zimbabwe’s education system.

news.title: 15 Regional and Residential Courts established in 2024
news.content:
Story by Peter Chivhima
The Judicial Service Commission (JSC) managed to set up 15 Regional and Residential Magistrate Courts this year as part of the drive to bring justice delivery closer to people’s door steps.
JSC Secretary Mr Walter Chikwana speaks on the strides realised in justice delivery this year.
“In 2024 the success has been unprecedented because we have never done it since the inception of the Judicial Service Commission in 2010. We have opened and established new regional magistrates in Guruve, Mutoko, Kwekwe, Zvishavane. The other four are already functional except for Guruve where we are now finalising and working on the logistical areas so that we have proper infrastructure that will house the regional court. So our numbers of regional magistrates have increased in that respect. We have also established close to 10 resident magistrates courts within the country. We have established a resident magistrate court in Mabvuku where again we are going to open a regional magistrate there. We have since commenced construction of the courthouse in Mabvuku and we are quite certain that during the course of the year the courthouse will be ready to be opened,” he said.

news.title: Roofing almost complete at Mbare Musika temporary market project
news.content:
Story by Memory Chamisa
The project to construct a temporary market to accommodate traders affected by a fire that razed Mbare Musika in October is on course, with the structure now at roofing level.
The construction works which began early this month have brought hope, with the residents near the construction site expressing satisfaction with the ongoing work.

news.title: Pottery saves Chitungwiza man from drug addiction
news.content:
Story by Memory Chamisa
Pottery has saved a 25-year-old Chitungwiza man, as the craft represents a dividing line in his life between drug abuse and finding purpose.
While some of his peers still abuse drugs and other substances, Gift Zirende, popularly known as MaCenturion has turned a new leaf and is optimistic about what the future holds for him.
Having hanged around the wrong crowd which contributed to him using drugs, MaCenturion received his Damascus moment when he met a well-wisher who took him in and rehabilitated him through pottery.
From just passing time, the craft has now become a part of his identity and purpose.
“I was a troubled young man and was always in trouble as I associated with the wrong crowd which contributed to a lot of wrong decisions I made in my life. It also affected my life to the extent that I was thrown out of our family home by parents. I became homeless and was taken in by a well-wisher who then taught me pottery,” he said.
